articles.title: Greek Greetings and Goodbyes for Couples
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Learning Greek greetings and goodbyes together as a couple creates beautiful daily rituals that strengthen both your relationship and your language skills. Greeks are warm and expressive people, and knowing how to greet your partner and their family properly will earn you immediate respect and affection.

Whether you are waking up together, saying goodbye before work, or greeting your partner's family, these phrases will help you navigate every situation with confidence and charm.

## Essential Daily Greetings

Start your Greek journey with these fundamental greetings that every couple should know:

### Time-Based Greetings

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±"
  translation="Good morning"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-MEH-rah"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…! ÎšÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬; (Good morning, my love! Did you sleep well?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·ÏƒÏ€Î­ÏÎ±"
  translation="Good evening"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-SPEH-rah"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·ÏƒÏ€Î­ÏÎ±, ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´Î¹Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…. Î ÏÏ‚ Î®Ï„Î±Î½ Î· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…; (Good evening, my heart. How was your day?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±"
  translation="Good night"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-NEEKH-tah"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¹Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…. ÎŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¬! (Good night, my sweet. Sweet dreams!)"
/>

<PhraseOfDay
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="Good morning, my love"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-MEH-rah ah-GHAH-pee moo"
  context="The perfect way to start every morning with your Greek partner"
/>

<CultureTip title="Greek Greeting Times" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
Greeks use ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ± (good morning) until around noon, ÎšÎ±Î»Î·ÏƒÏ€Î­ÏÎ± (good evening) from late afternoon onwards, and ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î± (good night) when parting for the night or going to sleep. Using the right greeting at the right time shows cultural awareness.
</CultureTip>

### Casual Greetings

<VocabCard
  word="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…"
  translation="Hi / Hello / Bye (informal, singular)"
  pronunciation="YAH-soo"
  example="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…, Î¼Ï‰ÏÏŒ Î¼Î¿Ï…! Î¤Î¹ ÎºÎ¬Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚; (Hi, baby! How are you?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ±Ï‚"
  translation="Hello / Goodbye (formal or plural)"
  pronunciation="YAH-sahs"
  example="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ±Ï‚! Î§Î±Î¯ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï€Î¿Ï… ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î³Î½Ï‰ÏÎ¯Î¶Ï‰. (Hello! Pleased to meet you.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î±"
  translation="Hey / Hi (very casual)"
  pronunciation="YAH"
  example="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î±! Î Î¿Ï ÎµÎ¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹; (Hey! Where are you?)"
/>

## Romantic Morning Greetings

Make your mornings special with these romantic Greek greetings:

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î®Î»Î¹Îµ Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="Good morning, my sunshine"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-MEH-rah EE-lyeh moo"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î®Î»Î¹Îµ Î¼Î¿Ï…. Î•Î¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î­Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¼Î· Î³Î¹Î± ÎºÎ±Ï†Î­; (Good morning, my sunshine. Are you ready for coffee?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, ÏŒÎ¼Î¿ÏÏ†Î® Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="Good morning, my beautiful"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-MEH-rah OH-mor-fee moo"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, ÏŒÎ¼Î¿ÏÏ†Î® Î¼Î¿Ï…. Î ÏÏ‚ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚; (Good morning, my beautiful. How did you sleep?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±ÏƒÏ„Î­ÏÎ¹ Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="Good morning, my star"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-MEH-rah ah-STEH-ree moo"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±ÏƒÏ„Î­ÏÎ¹ Î¼Î¿Ï…! Î•Î¯Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„ÏŒÏƒÎ¿ Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¿ÏÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï… Î¾ÏÏ€Î½Î·ÏƒÎ± Î´Î¯Ï€Î»Î± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…. (Good morning, my star! I'm so happy I woke up next to you.)"
/>

### Morning Questions

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬;"
  translation="Did you sleep well?"
  pronunciation="kee-MEE-thee-kes kah-LAH"
  example="ÎšÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬; - ÎÎ±Î¹, Ï…Ï€Î­ÏÎ¿Ï‡Î±! (Did you sleep well? - Yes, wonderfully!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î¤Î¹ ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± ÎµÎ¯Î´ÎµÏ‚;"
  translation="What dreams did you have?"
  pronunciation="tee OH-nee-rah EE-thes"
  example="Î¤Î¹ ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± ÎµÎ¯Î´ÎµÏ‚; Î•Î¯Î´Î± ÎµÏƒÎ­Î½Î±! (What dreams did you have? I dreamed of you!)"
/>

## How Are You? - The Essential Exchange

<VocabCard
  word="Î ÏÏ‚ ÎµÎ¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹;"
  translation="How are you?"
  pronunciation="pos EE-seh"
  example="Î ÏÏ‚ ÎµÎ¯ÏƒÎ±Î¹, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…; (How are you, my love?)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î¤Î¹ ÎºÎ¬Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚;"
  translation="How are you doing? / What are you doing?"
  pronunciation="tee KAH-nees"
  example="Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…! Î¤Î¹ ÎºÎ¬Î½ÎµÎ¹Ï‚; (Hi! How are you doing?)"
/>

### Common Responses

| Greek | English | Pronunciation |
|-------|---------|---------------|
| **ÎšÎ±Î»Î¬, ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï** | Fine, thank you | kah-LAH ef-hah-ree-STOH |
| **Î Î¿Î»Ï ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬** | Very well | poh-LEE kah-LAH |
| **ÎœÎ¹Î± Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¬** | Great / Just fine | MYAH hah-RAH |
| **ÎˆÏ„ÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÎ¹ Î­Ï„ÏƒÎ¹** | So-so | EH-tsee kee EH-tsee |
| **Î•ÏƒÏ;** | And you? | eh-SEE |

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î¬ ÎµÎ¯Î¼Î±Î¹, ÎµÏƒÏ;"
  translation="I'm good, and you?"
  pronunciation="kah-LAH EE-meh eh-SEE"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î¬ ÎµÎ¯Î¼Î±Î¹, ÎµÏ…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï. Î•ÏƒÏ; (I'm good, thank you. And you?)"
/>

<CultureTip title="Greek Warmth in Greetings" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
Greeks genuinely want to know how you are. Unlike some cultures where "How are you?" is just a formality, Greeks often expect a real answer and may share details about their day. Embrace this warmth and engage in the conversation!
</CultureTip>

## Romantic Goodbyes

Saying goodbye in Greek can be just as romantic as saying hello:

### Short Goodbyes

<VocabCard
  word="Î¦Î¹Î»Î¹Î¬"
  translation="Kisses (as a goodbye)"
  pronunciation="fee-LYAH"
  example="Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ! Î¦Î¹Î»Î¹Î¬! (Talk soon! Kisses!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ"
  translation="We'll talk / Talk soon"
  pronunciation="tah LEH-meh"
  example="Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Î±ÏÎ³ÏŒÏ„ÎµÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…! (Talk later, my love!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Ï„Î¿ Î²ÏÎ¬Î´Ï…"
  translation="We'll talk tonight"
  pronunciation="tah LEH-meh toh VRAH-thee"
  example="Î ÏÎ­Ï€ÎµÎ¹ Î½Î± Ï†ÏÎ³Ï‰. Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Ï„Î¿ Î²ÏÎ¬Î´Ï…! (I have to go. We'll talk tonight!)"
/>

### Leaving for Work

<VocabCard
  word="Î Î¬Ï‰ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î´Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¬"
  translation="I'm going to work"
  pronunciation="PAH-oh stee thoo-LYAH"
  example="Î Î¬Ï‰ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î´Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¬. Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Î±ÏÎ³ÏŒÏ„ÎµÏÎ±! (I'm going to work. Talk later!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î® Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î½Î± Î­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚"
  translation="Have a good day"
  pronunciation="kah-LEE MEH-rah nah EH-hees"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î® Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î½Î± Î­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…! (Have a good day, my love!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎÎ± Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚"
  translation="Take care / Be careful"
  pronunciation="nah proh-SEH-hees"
  example="ÎÎ± Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½ Î´ÏÏŒÎ¼Î¿! (Take care on the road!)"
/>

### Romantic Partings

<VocabCard
  word="Î˜Î± Î¼Î¿Ï… Î»ÎµÎ¯ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚"
  translation="I will miss you"
  pronunciation="thah moo LEE-psees"
  example="Î˜Î± Î¼Î¿Ï… Î»ÎµÎ¯ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï ÏƒÎ®Î¼ÎµÏÎ±. (I will miss you a lot today.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î‘Î½Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½Ï Î½Î± ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï‰"
  translation="I can't wait to see you"
  pronunciation="ah-nee-poh-moh-NOH nah seh thoh"
  example="Î‘Î½Ï…Ï€Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½Ï Î½Î± ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï‰ Ï„Î¿ Î²ÏÎ¬Î´Ï…! (I can't wait to see you tonight!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î£ÎºÎ­ÏˆÎ¿Ï… Î¼Îµ"
  translation="Think of me"
  pronunciation="SKEP-soo meh"
  example="Î£ÎºÎ­ÏˆÎ¿Ï… Î¼Îµ ÏƒÎ®Î¼ÎµÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…. (Think of me today, my love.)"
/>

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï. Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Î±ÏÎ³ÏŒÏ„ÎµÏÎ±!"
  translation="I love you. Talk later!"
  pronunciation="sah-ghah-POH tah LEH-meh ar-GHOH-teh-rah"
  context="Perfect for saying goodbye to your partner before work or errands"
/>

## Bedtime Goodbyes

End your day with these sweet bedtime phrases:

<VocabCard
  word="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="Good night, my love"
  pronunciation="kah-lee-NEEKH-tah ah-GHAH-pee moo"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…. Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï! (Good night, my love. I love you!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="ÎŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¬"
  translation="Sweet dreams"
  pronunciation="OH-nee-rah ghlee-KAH"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±! ÎŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¬! (Good night! Sweet dreams!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Îa Î¼Îµ Î¿Î½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎµÏ…Ï„ÎµÎ¯Ï‚"
  translation="Dream of me"
  pronunciation="nah meh oh-nee-ref-TEES"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…. ÎÎ± Î¼Îµ Î¿Î½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎµÏ…Ï„ÎµÎ¯Ï‚! (Good night, my love. Dream of me!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î˜Î± ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï‰ ÏƒÏ„Î± ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…"
  translation="I'll see you in my dreams"
  pronunciation="thah seh thoh stah OH-nee-rah moo"
  example="ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±. Î˜Î± ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï‰ ÏƒÏ„Î± ÏŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¬ Î¼Î¿Ï…. (Good night. I'll see you in my dreams.)"
/>

## Formal Greetings and Goodbyes

When meeting your partner's family or in formal situations, use these phrases:

<VocabCard
  word="Î§Î±Î¯ÏÏ‰ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï"
  translation="Pleased to meet you"
  pronunciation="HEH-roh poh-LEE"
  example="Î§Î±Î¯ÏÏ‰ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï. Î•Î¯Î¼Î±Î¹ Î¿ ÎœÎ¬Î¹ÎºÎ». (Pleased to meet you. I'm Michael.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î§Î±Î¯ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï€Î¿Ï… ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î³Î½Ï‰ÏÎ¯Î¶Ï‰"
  translation="I'm happy to meet you"
  pronunciation="HEH-roh-meh poo sahs gnoh-REE-zoh"
  example="Î§Î±Î¯ÏÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï Ï€Î¿Ï… ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ Î³Î½Ï‰ÏÎ¯Î¶Ï‰. (I'm very happy to meet you.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î‘Î½Ï„Î¯Î¿"
  translation="Goodbye (formal)"
  pronunciation="an-DEE-oh"
  example="Î‘Î½Ï„Î¯Î¿ ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÎºÎ±Î»Î® ÏƒÏ…Î½Î­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î±. (Goodbye and take care.)"
/>

<CultureTip title="Kisses in Greek Culture" flag="ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡·">
Greeks often greet close friends and family with kisses on both cheeks. When greeting your partner's relatives, follow their lead - if they lean in for cheek kisses, reciprocate warmly. This physical warmth is part of Greek hospitality.
</CultureTip>

## Reunion Greetings

When you see your partner after time apart:

<VocabCard
  word="ÎœÎ¿Ï… Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎµÏ‚!"
  translation="I missed you!"
  pronunciation="moo EH-lee-pses"
  example="ÎœÎ¿Ï… Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎµÏ‚ Ï„ÏŒÏƒÎ¿ Ï€Î¿Î»Ï! (I missed you so much!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î•Ï€Î¹Ï„Î­Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚!"
  translation="Finally!"
  pronunciation="eh-pee-TEH-loos"
  example="Î•Ï€Î¹Ï„Î­Î»Î¿Ï…Ï‚! Î ÎµÏÎ¯Î¼ÎµÎ½Î± ÏŒÎ»Î· Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î½Î± ÏƒÎµ Î´Ï‰! (Finally! I waited all day to see you!)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Î ÏÏ‚ Ï€Î­ÏÎ±ÏƒÎµÏ‚;"
  translation="How did it go? / How was it?"
  pronunciation="pos PEH-rah-ses"
  example="Î ÏÏ‚ Ï€Î­ÏÎ±ÏƒÎµÏ‚ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î´Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¬; (How was work?)"
/>

## Practice Scenarios for Couples

### Scenario 1: Morning Routine

**Partner A:** ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…! ÎšÎ¿Î¹Î¼Î®Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬; (Good morning, my love! Did you sleep well?)
**Partner B:** ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±! ÎÎ±Î¹, Ï€Î¿Î»Ï ÎºÎ±Î»Î¬. Î•ÏƒÏ; (Good morning! Yes, very well. And you?)
**Partner A:** ÎœÎ¹Î± Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¬! Î˜Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï†Î­; (Great! Do you want coffee?)

### Scenario 2: Leaving for Work

**Partner A:** Î Î¬Ï‰ ÏƒÏ„Î· Î´Î¿Ï…Î»ÎµÎ¹Î¬. Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ Î±ÏÎ³ÏŒÏ„ÎµÏÎ±! (I'm going to work. Talk later!)
**Partner B:** ÎšÎ±Î»Î® Î¼Î­ÏÎ± Î½Î± Î­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚! ÎÎ± Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ­Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Ï‚! (Have a good day! Take care!)
**Partner A:** Î•Ï…Ï‡Î±ÏÎ¹ÏƒÏ„Ï! Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï! (Thank you! I love you!)
**Partner B:** Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï ÎºÎ¹ ÎµÎ³Ï! Î˜Î± Î¼Î¿Ï… Î»ÎµÎ¯ÏˆÎµÎ¹Ï‚! (I love you too! I'll miss you!)

### Scenario 3: Bedtime

**Partner A:** ÎÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î¬Î¶Ï‰. Î Î¬Ï‰ Î³Î¹Î± ÏÏ€Î½Î¿. (I'm sleepy. I'm going to bed.)
**Partner B:** ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï…. ÎŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¬! (Good night, my love. Sweet dreams!)
**Partner A:** ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±. ÎÎ± Î¼Îµ Î¿Î½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎµÏ…Ï„ÎµÎ¯Ï‚! (Good night. Dream of me!)
**Partner B:** Î Î¬Î½Ï„Î±! Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï! (Always! I love you!)

## Quick Reference Card

| Situation | Greek | English |
|-----------|-------|---------|
| Morning | ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±, Î±Î³Î¬Ï€Î· Î¼Î¿Ï… | Good morning, my love |
| Afternoon/Evening | ÎšÎ±Î»Î·ÏƒÏ€Î­ÏÎ±, ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´Î¹Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï… | Good evening, my heart |
| Night | ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±, Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¹Î¬ Î¼Î¿Ï… | Good night, my sweet |
| Casual hi | Î“ÎµÎ¹Î± ÏƒÎ¿Ï…! | Hi! |
| Leaving | Î¤Î± Î»Î­Î¼Îµ! | Talk soon! |
| With love | Î£'Î±Î³Î±Ï€Ï, Ï†Î¹Î»Î¹Î¬! | I love you, kisses! |
| Missing them | ÎœÎ¿Ï… Î­Î»ÎµÎ¹ÏˆÎµÏ‚! | I missed you! |
| Sweet dreams | ÎŒÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¬! | Sweet dreams! |


Mastering Greek greetings and goodbyes transforms ordinary moments into opportunities for connection. Every "ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î¼Î­ÏÎ±" and "ÎšÎ±Î»Î·Î½ÏÏ‡Ï„Î±" becomes a small love letter when spoken in your partner's language.

Practice these phrases every day with each other. Let them become the rhythm of your relationship. Before long, greeting each other in Greek will feel as natural as breathing.

<CTA text="Ready to master Greek together?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

articles.title: Portuguese Articles: Definite and Indefinite
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Understanding Portuguese articles is fundamental to speaking correctly. Unlike English with just "the," "a," and "an," Portuguese has multiple articles that change based on gender and number. Mastering these small words makes a big difference in how natural your Portuguese sounds.

## Definite Articles: The

<PhraseOfDay
  word="O amor Ã© lindo"
  translation="Love is beautiful"
  pronunciation="oo ah-MOR eh LEEN-doo"
  context="Portuguese uses the definite article with abstract nouns like 'amor' where English does not"
/>

Portuguese has four definite articles corresponding to English "the":

<VocabCard
  word="O"
  translation="The (masculine singular)"
  pronunciation="oo"
  example="O homem estÃ¡ aqui. (The man is here.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="A"
  translation="The (feminine singular)"
  pronunciation="ah"
  example="A mulher Ã© bonita. (The woman is beautiful.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Os"
  translation="The (masculine plural)"
  pronunciation="ooz"
  example="Os livros estÃ£o na mesa. (The books are on the table.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="As"
  translation="The (feminine plural)"
  pronunciation="ahz"
  example="As flores sÃ£o lindas. (The flowers are beautiful.)"
/>

<CultureTip
  title="Articles with Names"
  flag="ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡·"
>
  In Brazilian Portuguese, it is common to use definite articles before people's names. You might hear "A Maria estÃ¡ chegando" (Maria is arriving). This is less common in European Portuguese.
</CultureTip>

## Indefinite Articles: A/An/Some

<VocabCard
  word="Um"
  translation="A/An (masculine singular)"
  pronunciation="oom"
  example="Um homem entrou na loja. (A man entered the store.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Uma"
  translation="A/An (feminine singular)"
  pronunciation="OO-mah"
  example="Uma mulher me ajudou. (A woman helped me.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Uns"
  translation="Some (masculine plural)"
  pronunciation="oonz"
  example="Comprei uns livros novos. (I bought some new books.)"
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Umas"
  translation="Some (feminine plural)"
  pronunciation="OO-mahz"
  example="Vi umas flores bonitas. (I saw some beautiful flowers.)"
/>

## When Portuguese Uses Articles Differently

### With Possessives

<CultureTip
  title="Brazilian vs Portuguese Usage"
  flag="ğŸ‡µğŸ‡¹"
>
  European Portuguese typically uses articles before possessives. You will hear "O meu carro" (my car) in Portugal, while Brazilians often say just "Meu carro."
</CultureTip>

<VocabCard
  word="O meu amor"
  translation="My love"
  pronunciation="oo MEH-oo ah-MOR"
  example="O meu amor por vocÃª Ã© eterno. (My love for you is eternal.) Common in Portugal."
/>

### With Countries and Places

<VocabCard
  word="O Brasil Ã© enorme"
  translation="Brazil is enormous"
  pronunciation="oo brah-ZEEL eh eh-NOR-mee"
  example="Most country names take articles in Portuguese. O Brasil, a FranÃ§a, os Estados Unidos."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Portugal Ã© lindo"
  translation="Portugal is beautiful"
  pronunciation="por-too-GAHL eh LEEN-doo"
  example="Some countries do not take articles. Portugal, Cuba, Israel."
/>

### With Days and Times

<VocabCard
  word="Na segunda-feira"
  translation="On Monday"
  pronunciation="nah seh-GOON-dah FAY-rah"
  example="Vamos sair na segunda-feira. (Let us go out on Monday.) Days require articles in Portuguese."
/>

## Essential Contractions

Portuguese articles combine with prepositions to form contractions. These are mandatory, not optional.

### De (of/from) + Articles

<VocabCard
  word="Do / Da / Dos / Das"
  translation="Of the / From the"
  pronunciation="doo / dah / doosh / dahsh"
  example="O livro do professor. (The teacher's book.) De + o = do."
/>

### Em (in/on) + Articles

<VocabCard
  word="No / Na / Nos / Nas"
  translation="In the / On the"
  pronunciation="noo / nah / noosh / nahsh"
  example="Estou na casa. (I am in the house.) Em + a = na."
/>

### A (to) + Articles

<VocabCard
  word="Ao / Ã€ / Aos / Ã€s"
  translation="To the"
  pronunciation="ow / ah / owsh / ahsh"
  example="Vou ao mercado. (I am going to the market.) A + o = ao."
/>

### Por (by/through) + Articles

<VocabCard
  word="Pelo / Pela / Pelos / Pelas"
  translation="By the / Through the"
  pronunciation="PEH-loo / PEH-lah / PEH-loosh / PEH-lahsh"
  example="Passamos pela praia. (We passed by the beach.) Por + a = pela."
/>

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

<VocabCard
  word="A problema (incorrect)"
  translation="The problem"
  pronunciation="oo proh-BLEH-mah"
  example="Correct: O problema. Despite ending in 'a,' problema is masculine. Always check gender."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Eu sou estudante (not um estudante)"
  translation="I am a student"
  pronunciation="EH-oo soh esh-too-DAHN-chee"
  example="With professions, Portuguese often omits the indefinite article unlike English."
/>

## Romantic Uses

<VocabCard
  word="VocÃª Ã© o amor da minha vida"
  translation="You are the love of my life"
  pronunciation="voh-SEH eh oo ah-MOR dah MEE-nyah VEE-dah"
  example="Note the contractions: da (de + a). Articles are essential in this romantic phrase."
/>

<VocabCard
  word="Uma noite especial"
  translation="A special night"
  pronunciation="OO-mah NOY-chee esh-peh-see-AHL"
  example="Quero planejar uma noite especial para vocÃª. (I want to plan a special night for you.)"
/>

Practice using articles naturally by describing things around you. Name objects with their correct article: o telefone, a mesa, os sapatos, as chaves. The more you practice, the more automatic correct article usage becomes.

<CTA
  text="Ready to perfect your Portuguese grammar with your partner?"
  buttonText="Start Learning Now"
/>
